description.text:
I needed a small shelf for a small PC speaker sub. So why not make the brackets for the shelf since I already have a 3D-printer? So I did. They worked out nicely so here they are for all to print. Measurements:
Top arm is 140mm (5.512in) long from wall to tip.
Bottom arm is 100mm (3.937in) long from shelf to tip.
Bracket is 10mm (0.393in) wide. Screw holes are 3.5mm (0.138in) in diameter and the screw head counter sink holes are 7mm (0.275) in diameter. Im shure you have something laying around that will fit. There are access holes for a manual screw driver for the innermost corner screws. A hole big enough for the bit extender of a power drill to fit trough would mean a wider bracket. Tip: Use an awl (Or whatever thin pointy thing you have laying around, a large nail works to.) and a hammer on the wall beforehand to make the screws easier to screw in by hand. It will also keep you from moving the bracket out of place. Or just apply generous amounts of brute force.

Pretty self explanatory. Print on the side laying down. No support or raft should be needed.  
If you are printing this in ABS then you might want to crank up the ambient temperature to avoid warping. It is a pretty long object after all. Those small contractions in the plastic add up when stuff becomes long.  
I got 17 grams of ABS used (per bracket) when doing 10% infill, and 19 grams when using 20%. So you might want to up it to 20% for a little extra stiffness and load capacity. The difference in material used was not that great.  
If you have other types of screws you can drill the holes up a bit. Depends on how many layers of plastic you used. More layers the stronger the part. I usually use 3 layers for load bearing items etc, so I have a bit of leeway to adjust things afterwards and the item does not end up to flimsy.  
Obviously shelfs using these brackets should not be used for really heavy items. But they will hold for most normal uses. Just use common sense, and don't sue me if you do not use common sense and decide to store your collection of cannon balls on it or something. Use at your own risk.

author: Nucklear

description.text:
This is a simple model of NASA's SLS rocket.  
I hope you have as much fun printing this as I did drawing and sharing it.

The rocket consists of 5 parts to make it easier to build.  
I printed this on the MakerBot Replicator 2X.  Each part took an hour or less to print.  I printed all parts vertically except the top.  I printed each of these at the “Low (Faster)” resolution using the MakerWare defaults (number of shells: 2, layer height: 0.30 mm, extruder speed: 90 mm/s, travel speed : 150 mm/s).  The only setting I changed was the infill to 25%.  
The top I printed horizontally.  I originally printed it vertically, but the abort motor came out like a nice swirled ice cream cone. I printed this part at the “Standard” resolution using the MakerWare defaults (number of shells: 2, layer height: 0.20 mm, extruder speed: 90 mm/s, travel speed : 150 mm/s)  Again I changed the infill to 25%.  
I used a raft on each part, but only used supports for the top and bottom parts.  The Replicator 2X allows me to print using a break away support material, but I also printed a copy using the build material as the support and I was able to remove it, just not as easily.  I did have a problem with it sticking to the build plate, but I paused the build after the raft was down and used blue painters tape to tape around the edges.  This worked every time.  
Depending on the shrink rate of the material used, you may be able to just snap all of the pieces together.  On a few builds, I occasionally had to lightly sand/file the pieces to get them to go together.  And on one occasion I had to glue the top piece, since it came out a little loose.  
I added a hole up through the center if you want to make a stand, but the rocket should stand vertically as built.  
I have scaled it up to 12 inches high, using the same MakerWare settings mentioned, and I have scaled it down to 6 inches, but for that I printed everything at the “Standard” resolution.

The .stl sizes are a bit wonky, but if you rescale everything to be 50mm in the z-direction, the pieces should fit perfectly with the originals.  
This was a pretty quick build, so the edges and alignments aren't super-clean and consistent, but it's good enough for my purposes.
These are the parts to create a cube. It consists of 19 "L" shaped four square pieces, 3 short "L" three part pieces, 6 two square pieces, and a single cube.

These pieces are like plastic mechano. They are meant to be glued together with a low temperature glue gun for an education project and then broken apart for the next group. We made them for a hydrogen fuel cell car workshop, as a collaboration between http://www.arcolaenergy.com/ and http://www.learning-to-learn.org.uk. Thanks to Simon who put together all the wheels and bars. The fuel cells come from Horizon:
http://www.arcolaenergy.com/store/ And we bought gearboxes from rapid:
http://www.rapidonline.com/Educational-Products/Electronics/Motors-Gearboxes/Economy-gearbox-and-motor/10556/kw/gearbox

Sheet 1:
The small circles are to be glued (with acrylic glue) onto the bigger circles to provide enough surface area for them to be hot glued onto 4mm axels. The longer bars with holes in are for holding the 4mm axels. Sheet 2:
This is probably only useful for fuel cell applications, as it holds a 5ml syringe pressurized with an elastic band.

These are pen holder desk plaques with inscriptions.  Example fonts are taken from thing:13677 - More Fontz by polymaker.  Here are four plaques using 16 different fonts.  The openSCAD code is easily changed to display ones favorite messages.

The plaques are open at one end and can be used as containers for pens.  There were some surprises; the fonts, as far as I can tell, are not uniform along the z axis.  I found it necessary to use openSCAD's mirror command to ensure that the fonts were displayed with their best sides uppermost.  If this is done one gets uniformly crisp characters for all 16 fonts.

A 3D printed secure mount for the Dremel 300 to go with the 3D Printed CNC mill on instructables. http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-printed-CNC-mill/ The mount is supplied in two halfs that bolt to the existing Z axis anti-backlash nut and then further bolt together to provide extra stability. The two halfs mount onto the Dremel in between the motor air intake to allow the Dremel to run without overheating. Printed using PLA and have run the CNC non-stop now for over two hours with everything staying cool and where it should be. http://youtu.be/llK1INxy1Ms

description.text:
Intended to be stamped from sheet metal, this scale mail armor is my industrial design project from the year 1337.  
7/8/15: Added files for fully articulated mail (LINK and LEAF), and top piece (EDGE).
1/22/16: Uploaded zip file containing IGES and Parasolid X_T formats of all the pieces.

Print on course (.3mm) with 10 shells. Takes about 1/2 an hour to print 12 pieces with no support or raft.  
Use a heat gun to soften the arms (medium heat). Make sure you shield the body from the heat gun (or hair dryer), or it will also become soft. I used a strip of wood underneath so the arms dropped as the heat was applied, and another piece on top as a heat shield.  10 seconds is about all it takes.  
Once the arms drop 90 degrees, stop heating. It is safe to handle with your fingers to work. bend arms over a steel washer to keep bends wide. Pinch ends close together inside the eye of the washer against the body to make a nice loop.  
After the arms are bent and cooled for a few seconds they will be hard. The tip of a razor blade under the loops helps lift them for assembly.  
The patch in the pictures took 2 hours to print , and 2 hours to bend and assemble.

description.text:
This is a revised drive block derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125
I used OpenSCAD to mirror the STL files after I resaved them from Meshlab. They wouldn't load correctly before. I changed the size of the bearing axle to accomodate a 5x10x4mm bearing that is easily available from any hobby shop that carries 1/10th scale cars. I made the pivot screw hole slightly larger, and shaved off the top of the lever to fit in the replicator 1. There are mirrored versions for the left extruder as well.

Just like the original, use 3 shells, 10% infill with .20mm layers. You can print these files as is if you have the bearings I got, or use the .scad file to adjust to your specifications. I might make this thing use customizer if it is ever able to load .stl files.
5mm bearing plate files:
Rep1 Right Plate 5mm.stl (Use for a single Replicator, or right side)
Rep1 Left Plate 5mm.stl (Use for the left side of a Replicator Dual) To use the .scad file, download these files and put them into any folder together when you run it:
partfix.scad
ExtruderBase.stl
ExtruderCap.stl
ExtruderLever.stl (These are the original files, but fixed to work with .scad) I colored the additional parts red, and the subtracted parts green. You can play with the settings to make your parts fit. Uncomment the begining lines to make your selected part.

A new version of the tensioner, Scribble?  After less than a week?
Don't panic.  It's not all that new.  I've just been refactoring the OpenSCAD code to make it /fully/ parametric.  This is an early step in some bigger ideas I'm working on.
What does this mean?
It means you can tell the OpenSCAD script the size of your bolts and your bearings, as well as some other bits and ends,  and it will design a Wade's-style tensioner exactly to your specifications.  No M3 bolts?  No problem; just change the size.  No 606 bearings?  No problem!  Anything goes!  You like more column supports?  Just change the setting.  None?  OK!  Leave off the DC motor bolt holes?  You can do that!
I've uploaded a couple photos of the 608 part I printed here compared to the original, but that's not completely fair since it should be photos of two different versions generated from /this/ script...  I'm really just uploading them now so there's more pretty pictures to look at.  
UPDATED: 
I'm calling this script complete now.  I'm sure there's still a few bugs to work out, but it should be feature complete, as far as what I'd originally intended.  I've got some more things to work on now, related but probably not changing the design of this directly any more.
Incidentally, I added an option for a cleaning hole.
UPDATE:
There will be one more version of this coming - I managed to learn how to get proper measurements out of the original parts and found my holes are off by the tiniest amount.  It shall be fixed; I've already got the changes mostly written.

You can tell the script the thickness of all your bolts, how thick to make the motor connector and the hot end connector, and the size of your bearings.  You can also add additional length to either dimension to give your idler block bolts better clearance.
The script does not presently sanity-check your options.  There is a generate_for_viewing option I suggest you turn on and examine the model to make sure nothing critical is overlapping in your design.  Especially make sure there is at least a couple layers clearance between the long idler block bolts and the filament shaft, and bearing/motor shaft.  Also look for clearance for bolts behind/below the idler block.
If your idler block bolts need repositioning, you can simply add extra_shaft to help it clear the filament better and extra_filament to help it clear the motor shaft better.  If that seems backwards, it's because the extra length along the filament dimension will give you more clearance along the shaft dimension - it makes sense if you think about it.
If your idler block needs additional clearance from the bolts, you can increase motor_bolt_hex_h and base_bolt_hex_h -- these options control how much space is reserved for the boltheads or hex nuts.  Another option, perhaps to use together, is the base_dropbolts and motor_dropbolts options, which sink the space reserved for the nuts into the respective surface.
When you run the script, not only will it create a model exact to your specifications, it will also output some vital information for your shopping trip and construction:
1) The (minimum) length of M8 (or whatever size you specified) bolt you will need for the idler block...  If the only bolt you can find it longer, it can just hang out the front a little.
2) The (minimum) length of motor shaft or bolt you will need (measured from the back of this part; so remember to add on whatever length you need to put inside your gear if you are using an externally geared stepper!)
3) How far along the motor shaft you must place your hobbing, or the MK5 plastic pusher gear.
The parameters in the file are heavily commented.  Feedback is greatly appreciated!  For you OpenSCAD users, this includes modules for generating MK5 boltholes for motor mounts and hot end mounts!  I dunno if such things exist elsewhere; if so, the elsewhere versions are probably better.

description.text:
Möbius strips with 1, 3, 5, and 7 twists. These .stl files were exported straight from Mathematica, and then run though Netfabb to repair a few defects in the mesh . Sometimes shapes like the Möbius can have problems with their normal orientation, but I think these are ok for printing. They check out as "orientable" in Netfabb's analysis anyway. I've printed them all without problems. Here is the Mathematica code I used, for those who are interested in such things... twists = 5; ( number of twists)
width = 1.2; ( width of "ribbon" )
thickness = 1; ( thickness of "ribbon" ) Export["5twistmobius.stl", ParametricPlot3D[{(1 + v/2Cos[twists/2u])Cos[u], (1 + v/2Cos[twists/2u])Sin[u], v/2Sin[twistsu/2]}, {u, 0, 2*Pi}, {v, -width, width},
PlotStyle -> Thickness[thickness], PlotPoints -> 10,
MaxRecursion -> 5]]; ParametricPlot3D[{(1 + v/2Cos[twists/2u])
Cos[u], (1 + v/2Cos[twists/2u])Sin[u], v/2Sin[twistsu/2]}, {u,
0, 2*Pi}, {v, -width, width}, PlotStyle -> Thickness[thickness],
PlotPoints -> 20, MaxRecursion -> 10]

title: Switch plate with Buss bar connector

description.text: I made this switchplate and connection to have a handy way of connecting and controlling things like the LED's and motor cooling fans on my Prusa Mendel.

Print the switch plate, mounting clamp, and as many of the connectors as you need.
The buss bar and connectors are sized for 24 gauge wire. I use solid wire on the buss bar and stranded wire in the connectors.
Assemble things as shown in the pictures. Wrap the buss wire through the holes on each end of the buss bars and make sure it's nice and tight across the top of the bar.
You may need to clean out the holes in the connectors with a solid wire or small drill. make sure the wire is exposed on the inside of the connector and the connectore seats tightly on the buss bar. I used a #4x1/2" sheet metal screw to connect the switch plate to the bar clamp, and 3mm capscrew, nut, and washers to secure the bar clamp on my printer. The bar clamp also makes a great general purpose mounting bracket for things like LED's.

-This thing is not about the .STL file, this thing contains instructions of how to change filaments while printing with your 3D printer- This method is for single extruder printer and works for all printer that uses .gcode file to print and can print from a SD card To change filaments while printing, you need to enter a few lines of codes in the .gcode file of any part you wishes to print, print the part, wait for the printer to pause, change the filament and enter M24. It’s relatively simple. You’ll be able to choose at exactly which layer the color will change. Look for instructions in the instructions tab Because it is not about downloading the .STL file, if you use my method or simply find it useful, make sure to like and/or reference this page!

1- Slice your .STL and save .gcode in SD card
2- Find, in your host, (I’m using Repetier) exactly at which layer the color needs to change. Let it be N.
( In my example, layer 8 is first layer with letters instead of being the rectangle base, thus N=8)
3- Find the height of that layer with this formula : (N-1) layer thickness + 1first layer thickness = answer
(My first layer thickness is 0.3 mm, subsequents are 0.15 mm. 7.15+1.3 = 1.35 mm)
4- Find the exact height in .gcode file. I suggest to open it with Notepad and press Ctrl+F, then enter G1 Z… where … is your height
(My line reads : G1 Z1.350 F7800.000)
5- Right after G1 Z… F…, paste this: G91 ; use relative coordinates
G1 Z15 ; extruder up 15 mm
M25 ; pause sd card reading, now is the time to change filament!
G91 ; use relative coordinates
G1 Z-15 ; extruder down 15 mm
G90 ; use absolute coordinates
G92 X… Y… Z… E0 ; set all axes in right position Replace all … with right value. After X and Y, write last coordinates that were sent before G1 Z… (step 4). Generally, you’ll find them 3 lines before G1 Z… . After Z, write your height calculated at step 3. (For me, I had these lines of code. In bold are lines I added)
…
G1 X76.794 Y15.456 E62.94156
G1 X33.206 Y15.456 E64.22251
G1 F1800.000 E63.22251
G92 E0
G1 Z1.350 F7800.000
G91 ; use relative coordinates
G1 Z15 ; extruder up 15 mm
M25 ; pause sd card reading, now is the time to change filament
G91 ; use realative coordinates
G1 Z-15 ; extruder down 15 mm
G90 ; use absolute coordinates
G92 X33.206 Y15.456 Z1.350 E0 ; set all axes in right position
G1 X56.345 Y24.970 F7800.000
G1 E1.00000 F1800.000
G1 X55.764 Y25.861 E1.01990 F1890.000
… Note where I found X33.206 and Y15.456 that a wrote on command G92 6- Save and print with SD card
7- Wait for the printer to stop and the change the filament by retracting (manual control). Purge the remaining plastic of the wrong color by extruding (manual control). When color coming out of nozzle is the right one, clean up the nozzle.
8- Enter M24 (resume SD printing) in your host. It should go down 15 mm and then resume printing.
9- You're done!
10- There is no step 10, you’re already done I told you. It may seem complicated at first, but I assure you, once you know what you’re doing it’s very simple. Hope you like it!

title: Base Plate for a Roland MDX-15

description.text:
Make all the base plates you want with a laser cut plate.
If made of acrylic you can drill into it with no worries. find related projects at http://www.makeitlabs.com/ in the wiki projects

laser cut. A thick plate will need to be machined around the positive stops in the back, and the screw holes in the front. The "a" plate is the working space with the pins from the base plate and a 1" grid. Reduce the laser power to min, and go to max speed and they will be faint marks for alignment. Glue or use VHB tape. Due to stack up tolerance the plate(s) may need to surfaced or corrected with shims.

author: 2ROBOTGUY

description.text:
2 hours Cinema 4D modeling with subdivision over 3 photos.
Pretty easy to digitize :) Real size 39 european measure :) Printed on Replicator 2 but can fit perfect on Prusa i3 bed.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15% or more :)

"Igor, throw the switch!"  
"Yes, master."

Update:
It's coming up on Halloween so I figured it's high time I add versions without the built-in supports that have been giving some printers fits. Use the switchplate files: "xxx_nosupport.stl" and turn on the supports option in your slicer. Update:
Just added: a 3 switch version for "Decora" paddle-type switches. It uses the same paddlenubbin used for the 1 switch version, and the same "Nx" blade used for the multi-switch (standard-type) switch plate. (If I get too many more versions, I'll need to add switchplate configurator utility.) Update:
Just added: a single switch version for "Decora" paddle-type switches (http://store.leviton.com/1-Gang-Single-Various-Available-WSS0S-D0/dp/B00700SHBW#.VO4DJ_nF-ws). You'll need the paddle_switchplate, paddlenubbin, and the madsci_blade. This version is a little different: because the modern looking paddle would look out of place, I hid it entirely underneath the switchplate and it uses a nubbin piece that fits through the plate. Update:
I've added 2 switch and 3 switch versions! The same nubbin part (1 per switch) is used for all versions. The standard blade part is used for the standard 1 switch plate, but the Nx blade (1 per switch) is used for the 2x and 3x plates. Update:
I've also added an alternate version of the nubbin that prints on its side (and without support ribs). Use this version if your printer handles bridges fairly well.

Printed in PLA with 0.2mm layers, 3 perimeter shells, and 20% infill.  (You might want to print the plate part a little hotter than normal to insure good layer adhesion.)  
Rotating the plate + or - 45 degrees before slicing (or alternately, setting the infill angle to 0 or 90 degrees) will make the top infill lines run with the grain of the "wood", for a more refined look, or else across the grain, for a rough-sawn look.  You'll have to preview the slicer output to see which orientation of the top layer lines you end up with.  
All parts print without support, but the switch plate and nubbin have ribs that break away before assembly.  If you have adhesion  trouble with the built-in support ribs, try printing with a 1 layer thick raft.

comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: I originally designed it to be printed the way it is because I was worried that if I printed it on its side (like Bassna's version), the ragged underside of the bridging might affect the fit.  Strength isn't really so much of an issue with this part, but In retrospect, I think it will work fine on its side, and then I could eliminate the annoying ribs.  I'll probably post an alternate nubbin soon that will print on its side.

comments.text: Try setting a thinner line width for the first layer (you can do this in slic3r).  The ribs go all the way down to the ground but if the slicer is using a thicker line width for the first layer, it may think they are too thin to print for just the first layer.  (The ribs are 0.8mm thick.)    If you still have problems, I'll post a version without the ribs.
comments.author: vcolombo

comments.text: Please post a version without the ribs
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: I had my width set at .4mm with the first layer set to 200%, so it's odd that it wouldn't have printed the ribs at .8mm thick, but setting my first layer to 100% seems to have resolved the issue.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/gQQHako4ete

A "wireframe" Möbius band created in Mathematica. I haven't been able to create a successful print of it yet - not even with our Form-1+, but you are welcome to give it a try. The Mathematica code is... f[u, v] := {(Cos[u] + .2v (Sin[u/2]) Cos[u]), (Sin[u] + .2 v (Sin[u/2])), vCos[u/2]};
scale = 40;
radius = 1.5;
gridSteps = 6;
curvesU = Table[scalef[u, i], {i, -1, 1, 2/gridSteps}];
curvesV = Table[scale*f[j, v], {j, -3, 3, 2/gridSteps}]; tubesU = ParametricPlot3D[curvesU, {u, -12, 12},
PlotStyle -> Tube[radius], PlotRange -> All];
tubesV = ParametricPlot3D[curvesV, {v, -1, 1},
PlotStyle -> Tube[radius], PlotRange -> All]; output = Show[tubesU, tubesV] Export["MathematicaMoebius.stl", output]

title: Catan Pieces As Starcraft And Warcraft Figures

description.text: I love playing the board game Settlers of Catan and I also love the video games from Blizzard so when I got a 3D printer the first big project I wanted to tackle was to recreate the board and pieces in 3D with the pieces being from Blizzard Games. If you want to make this you will still need to buy the game to get the necessary cards and such. I’ll be posting the board tiles in a different site. To learn more: https://recklessrobbie.wordpress.com
Nothing should need supports.  The Terran buildings have built in supports you will have to remove.  After building all these I probably could have made them 5-10% larger.

comments.text: Just as a note:  Don't print the Orc all at once, because the extruder has to vibrate it makes the roads extremely vulnerable to lifting, and it's even happened to the A base once or twice for me.
comments.author: Precision3DPrinting

comments.text: Where's the Night elves?  Otherwise looks great!
comments.author: Precision3DPrinting

comments.text:
I tried making Night Elves but ran into 2 problems.
The first one is that there isn't much difference between the different levels of the buildings.
The second is that the top heaviness and arms make it hard to print.
Which is a bummer because I would have really liked to have all Warcraft 3 races in there.
comments.author: Precision3DPrinting

comments.text: I think I have a solution, with two options.  The roads shouldn't be a problem either way, so I won't talk about those.  1:  You could use an Ancient of War as the town and tree of life as the city, or 2:  The better solution.  You could use a tree of life (simplified so it's basically just a really fat tree with a face) as the town, and then the actual model as a city, but with the arms touching the ground.  That would also explain why you couldn't slap the robber when he comes for you.
comments.author: RecklessRobbie

comments.text: I see, and that does make sense.  To solve the first you could choose a different building that looks similar to the tree of life but isn't it, then have the tree of life for the B base.  But as for the arms, I don't know how to fix that either, except for using supports.  Overall I think it could work but it would take more precision and work that the other races would, and would be a little off from the uniform.
comments.author: RecklessRobbie

The original NCC-1701, Constitution-class starship. Boldly going where no Thing has gone before.
Captain's Log, July 7, 2013: Version 2 is now available. Look for "NCC-1701_V2.zip". Gaps have been increased to 0.3 mm and seem to work well with a little edge cleanup. I've also added a display stand in the shape of the original series badge.

Just print all 10 components and glue them together. Use a piece of 1.75 mm filament to support the deflector dish. I used a contact clearance of 0.2 mm for the pylons. If this does not work, I'll post a revised model. Happy printing!
UPDATE, 7/7/13: See update in description. I also recommend not gluing the nacells to the pylons, or the pylons to the hull. That way you can take it apart for travel.

comments.text: "Ears" are helper disks. It's an option in Makerware and it's somewhere on Thingiverse, but I can't find it at the moment. It's a little disk of plastic that you put down at the edge of your model. Then it helps hold the model to the bed, and you can also use it to help pull the model off the bed. Very handy.
comments.author: sitts314

comments.text:
A remark from Joseph Chui reminded me to try ears. This was easier to do from Makerware, so I used that. Ears prevented the model from detaching from the base, but it did cause some cracking in the model itself, in the saucer section. I filled in the cracks with some ABS strands and acetone.
The pylon/nacelle fit is quite good.
One thing about the ears, they also filled in the hole for the filament that holds the deflector dish. But, the hole was too small anyway. Also, I had to print the deflector dish with support. It's behind the dish, so you don't see it too much.
Next trick will be to trim off the ears, neatly. I need a better pair of diagonal cutters.

I have the need to mount a tool on a base that can be freely swung between two 'arms'. This is a sibling of the tri-tool base: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5874 It integrates the axle holders which will accept something that is 5/16" in diameter (fully configurable in the OpenScad). You could use this tool base to mount something like a hot end for 3D printing, or a rotary tool, or a suction system, or a grasper, or pen, or...

1) Look at the robot you want to build and decide you need one of these tool holders
2) Measure and adjust sizes to fit your needs
3) Print one out
4) Attach whatever axle arrangement you want into the axle holders
5) Integrate into your robot
6) Rejoice! By default, the axle holders will accomodate something that is 5/16" outer diameter. I put brass bushings in there for a friction fit. You can make it any size you like, things will auto adjust. I attach these rod ends to the axle: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6295 You'll have to adjust the separation appropriately. The four mounting holes around the central hole are M3 by default, and hard coded for 5mm away from the central hole.

description.text: A strong small clip for carrying and storing tripods and other devices with camera thread (1/4 - 20 or 3/8 - 16) I have tested it to hold 10kg where after the metal ring broke. The clip all so works well as a string pod. Just add a thread rod, cut a bolt to size or buy a 1/4 to 1/4 Adapter and tie a line through the ring and you are done.

There are three models:
  • Is a model that takes a 1/4 - 20 thread repair insert.
  • A model that uses the camera conversion thread which comes with many tripods. (3/8 - 16 to 1/4 - 20)
  • This model uses a 3/8 - 16 thread repair insert.
    • Print the selected model with 100% fill or at least with wall thickness enough to handle the thread insert / converter Then used screw in the thread with no glue needed, it can however be added for even stronger connection. If you want to test if your printer is able to print the thread correctly then you can start with this thread repair test: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:646221

Against all instincts, a sphere is not the only geometric shape that has a constant diameter. There are an infinite amount of others, of which the Meissner Tetrahedron is the coolest. This set contains 4 shapes, each different, but with the same constant width of 35mm:
  • Meissner Tetrahedron
  • Revolved Reuleaux Triangle
  • Revolved Reuleaux Pentagon
  • Revolved Reuleaux Heptagon
    • I know this isn't the first collection on Thingiverse, but I CAD'ed them myself, hence no credits to others. Well, okay, credits to Reuleaux and Meissner! Watch them do their thing on http://youtu.be/_8Fe-OLr42Y If you make them, please share the picture!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1lSOTSdA59U A battery holder for a V2 ultrasaber. This is made to accomodate the buckpuck current regulator and 2 of the Li-ion batteries.

in order to complete this, you will need to add conductors. there is a slot in the bottom which can be used to add a conductor between the + terminal of one battery and the - terminal of the other.  
At the top, there is room to feed the Vin wires of the buckpuck to the opposite sides of the battery. You will need to add some sort of contact to the wires.  
There is about 1mm of extra clearance for the batteries, I recommend that you insert foam to cradle the batteries securely, but for my print, I found that it's good enough with the contact springs to not rattle.  
The + and - wires for the LED output from the buckpuck can exit from the top of the holder, and go to a switch, then to the LED.  
The outer dimensions are suitable for V2 ultrasabers. I used this to replace the 4AAA battery holder and resistor that mine came with.

title: Orangutan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Your Wild World's next animal is the majestic orangutan. They might not move in a very majestic way on the ground, but they are truly amazing animals. Orangutans share 97% of their genetic make up with humans. They are more like our furry cousins then strange beasts. They have an incredible intelligence and amazing personalities. It is said that if you give an orangutan an candy bar, they will brake it in half and give you the rest back. Not only are these animals an awesome spectacle of nature, but sadly they are growing more scarce in the wild. We also made this print to raise awareness of the diminishing orangutan population. They are very likely to be the next great ape to go extinct. It is important to we do what we can to help this species survive. Any thing you can do to avoid rain-forest products will be much appreciated by orangutans everywhere. Here are a couple very cool videos we stumbled across about orangutans. We hope you enjoy them as much as we did. Very cool orangutan rehabilitation video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oir_PSJpbAA The DIY orangutans (any maker should really enjoy this):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFACrIx5SZ0 Cool video about two friends (an orangutan and a dog):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MDStH49W5Hk We are only using these videos to raise awareness for orangutans, and in no way are they our videos.

For single extruders:
Download the orangutan_single_extruder.stl file.We used 10% infill. 2 shells, and we do recommend a raft and supports just for the very bottom. The exterior supports option in Replicator G worked very well. It is very possible you can get away with print without supports too. For dual extruders:
Download and merge the orangutan_and_nose.stl file and the mouth_and_eyes.stl file. We used 10% infill, 2 shells, and merge and sliced with Replicator G. We used exterior support and a raft on the extruder printing the orangutan_and_nose.stl file, and no supports or raft on the mouth_and_eyes.stl file.

Just another spool holder.  This one is specifically reinforced to handle 2 bolt mounting on a single 20 x 20 aluminum extrusion with elevated exterior tabs to prevent the spool from potentially walking off.  It can also sit on any flat surface as well.

1) Print
2) Drop in 4 608ZZ bearings
3) Run bolts through to retain bearings
4) Mount to frame(washers suggested to increase bolt head area for stability
5) Set spool on top with filament feeding over the top of the pool and down towards the loop on the inner portion of the holder
6) Run filament through guide loop(if its mounted to aluminum extrusion, dont if its sitting on a flat surface)
7) Insert filament into extruder I printed using SeeMeCNC ABS 1.75 grey filament at 227c nozzle, 115c bed. .3mm layer height and 3 perimeters, 60% infill. You could probably print with as low as 40% infill.

comments.text: Great design, I'm printing one off as I type this. I have to be honest though, I think this would be much better without the middle piece and by just presenting it as a single piece that you print twice. First of all, that middle bridge is completely unnecessary, you can just position the two side pieces where they are needed. Secondly, it would allow you to better position them for smaller reels e.g. 250g filament. Third, it would dramatically reduce the size of the print itself and reduce the risk of edge warping, something that is a significant problem when printing pieces of this size with PLA on an unheated bed.

Another power supply cover.  Designed with access hole to the voltage adjustment pot and LED using standard switch/connector cannibalized from an ATX power supply.  This was for an upgrade to a 24 volt power supply.

1) Print(note there is a decent length bridge of around 2 cm, so if you have problems with bridges make sure to use support)
2) Place cover on power supply, determine where screws should be run through on the sides
3) Drill holes in cover for retaining screws
4) Solder wires to the power outlet(unless you left them on and cut the wires from the ATX power supply pcb)
5) Bend the power outlet wire tabs over so they lay flat against the outlet
6) Pop the switch and outlet into the case
7) Solder the outlet wires to the switch
8) Run the wires in from the printer through the hole next to the outlet
9) Connect all the wires
10) Push cover into place
11) Screw cover to power supply Printed with SeeMeCNC ABS 1.75 grey filament at 227c nozzle, 115c bed and 40% infill.

title: Bead Roller Coaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This week's FriDIY item is the classic bead roller coaster (or maze) we probably all had as a little kid. I certainly remember having a blast with these when I was about 4. Now with the Your Wild World Bead Roller Coaster, you can print out your own fully customizable toy! Add as many blocks as you like to this modular toy and go as big as you want! We also provided a set of beads you can print out, but this just scratches the surface of what you can actually use for beads. We wanted to use filament for the wire, but it's absurdly difficult to manipulate and has very little rigidity. Braided filament was an even worse idea. We settled on 14 gauge picture hanging wire, available at most hardware stores for about $6.00 USD. This is an aluminum single stand wire that's easy to bend by hand, and can be snipped easily with wire cutters. Go nuts with this print! We want to see the craziest and biggest bead roller coasters you can make! Check out our blog post on this print:
http://www.yourwildworld.com/fridiy-bead-roller-coaster/

Print out the connector cubes, and the support rails. Start connecting and building your platform. Go as big or as small as you want.  
Bend your 14 gauge wire into position. Once you have everything sorted out and arranged the way you like, we recommend using a strong adhesive to connect the connector cubes and support rails and wire into the blocks. This will ensure the print holds up to the intense rigors of children.  
We printed all parts with 10% infill, 2 shells, and low resolution. The cubes should only take about 10 min a piece to print, and the rails are just as fast.

title: Garmin sandbag GPS mount to GoPro mount conversion

description.text:
So I had one of these Garmin dash sand bag mounts for a 12 year old GPS that I never use and I decided to convert it to a GoPro mount.  
The Garmin units have a non skip rubber on the back and 4 pouches with some kind of weighted material that makes the mount excellent for non permanent mounts. Here in California it's illegal to mount anything directly to the windshield like the suction cup mounts.

Sorry but I used U.S. standard screws because it's what I have on hand.  
Remove the old mount from the bag by the 4 screws located on the bottom. Drill them so a 4-40 bolt can pass through. Print the mount solid with 1 perimeter and 100% infill (trust me) and main block in the middle is hollow and won't use a lot of material and you need the strength.  
Use 4 X 4-40 screws to fasten the printed part down. The 4-40 screws I had were very long so I assembled the unit then cut them off with a Dremel so I am not sure their exact length.  
Finally epoxy a M5 Acorn nut into the GoPro mount socket (I like J-B Kwik for this. Be sure not to get epoxy into the threads or opening of the nut.  After the epoxy sets up you are ready to go.

I love playing the board game Settlers of Catan and I also love the video games from Blizzard so when I got a 3D printer the first big project I wanted to tackle was to recreate the board and pieces in 3D with the pieces being from Blizzard Games. The board is mainly modeled after the Warcraft III scenery. If you want to make this you will still need to buy the game to get the necessary cards and such. I made enough tiles for the 6 player version. If you only want the 4 player version you don’t need to make all of these. I’ll be posting the other board tiles in different posts. For the thief in order to tie in another Blizzard game I took this Diablo model and added a base.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18364 For the number tiles I used these:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40886
(you may want to print at 95%. Mine were a tight fit) To learn more go to:
https://recklessrobbie.wordpress.com

description.text:
This is a docking station I made for a standard G-Pen. It has 6 spots for extra tanks or batteries. I have included a version without the G logo on it for other vaporizer pens, but I can't guarantee they will fit. If you're looking for a matching set of accessories for your G-Pen, then check out these other things: G-Pen Herb Grinder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:649078
G-Pen 1/2 Ounce Herb Container: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:647633

This piece is designed to have 3mm dia magnets embedded in its side.  When several are printed they can be assembled into a gyroid shape.
The sample was printed in a Stratasys BST-768.  I'm not really sure how this would go on a MakerBot.

Each gyroid block requires 12 magnets (be careful to install them with alternating polarities.)
The 3mm dia x 3mm long magnets can be found at Gaussboys.  Product #C0303.  They are about $0.08 each.

author: DViktor

description.text: SPECIAL GEAR

Update 3/25/13 REV 1.5: I made quite a few changes to the original design of the parts, for the better I think. I am planning on using the 3 pulleys that I just printed out on the job tomorrow. We are pulling a long section of fiber and are short handed. I am hoping to use these in place of some bodies. The plastic will be nice because there is very little risk of cutting into the outer jacket. I made use of the Acetone bath technique for finishing these pulleys. It looks like the acetone and ABS solution really helped seal the outer shell. I am hoping they resist cracking at the seams now. See the change log for more info and see the photos for the updated version. REV 1.5**
Change Log:

  • Increased diameter of hole in the roller and frame. There is now minimal (almost no) post processing of the parts required.

  • Added a single roller to the design.

  • Removed decorative loop on top of frame

  • Decreased diameter and changed the shape of the end cap post to reduce overall post processing. End cap may require a touch of glue to stay secure now.

  • Changed to shape of end cap receiver in the rod to reflect changes in end cap post.
    • REV 1.0 I made this just to have something to play with. I might print another and hang my spools with them. As of right now this thing doesn't fit together with out some modifications. I had to ream out all of the holes with an exact-o knife and ended up glueing on the end cap of the rod. I am still new to 3D printing but I can see that this design does not compliment the material. It is still fun to play with though. Let me know what you end up using it for. I included the sketchup file. Feel free to fix and repost. :)
I had to add a brim to the frame rod in order for them to print with out moving. It also helps to print them seperately since they are so small. The over all demensions are 59Hx29Wx24D mm.

description.text: This is a simple adjustable-volume straw pipette. It should be very useful around any wet lab and works nicely with a relatively high range of possible volume settings. You can calibrate the volume but it is generally only good for low precision work. The pipette has two thumb nuts for adjusting upper and lower stops. To complete the build you will also need a spring (Pez dispenser) but it may work without as the membrane is elastic, a kids balloon, drinking straw, and some tape. Good luck! See a demo: http://youtu.be/N2Ax4OGokGM

Print the upper body, lower body, plunger, and two thumb gears. You will need a spring, which I got from a kids Pez dispenser for its form factor. The balloon membrane is elastic so you may get away without the spring but it is nicer to have it. You will also need a balloon, some tape, and a straw. It is designed for one particular straw diameter but I can upload others if there is demand. See the attached photos for assembly steps. I printed all the pieces at 0.1mm with 15% fill and 100% fill for the plunger.

Included in the parts for this are models of the required equipment with part numbers from McMaster.  2x #10-32 x 1 1/8" cap screws, 2x #10-32 Nuts, and 1x 8-32 x 7/8" Button Head Cap Screw. comments.text: What material?  These parts were setup to run on ABS, and I had to do a bit of filing in the picatinny groove on mine to get it to fit, you may be able to scale it up 1% or so to get it to fit a little better.
comments.author: superpotatofudge

comments.text: Hatchbox PLA which I haven't noticed as much shrinkage with as ABS. I measure 0.8105"(20.59mm) internal width, point to point, for the handle and 0.8375"(21.28mm) width for the rail on the cup. That would take quite a lot of filing. Plus the height of the profile is off by a good margin even if the width were correct. I did take a look at your other carry handle, Punisher version, and you said there that you updated the profile, but I haven't had a chance to compare them yet. Nor am I terribly good with modeling work yet.
comments.author: gwidgery

comments.text: Gotcha, I built 1.5 to 2.5% shrink into the models for ABS shrink, For the one carry handle I think I the profile is wrong, The punisher one I measured finished parts and adjsuted my models to fit.  The Punisher carry handle is too big for standard picatinny, but will fit the tacticoozie (Coozie rail is bigger).  It's kind of difficult to calculate shrink as it is varies based on thickness of material, infill, and geometry.  If I were you I'd just stand it on end and cancel the print after 5% or so and check fitment and scale it accordingly.  Just my 2 cents.  Post some pics to the made file when you get done.  Does the coozie fit a can in PLA or is it loose?  Mine fits just right with no slop in ABS.

comments.text: Yup to V3! Ah that explains how you got it mounted! If I had any standard non-ff rifles I'd print that and give it a try. Also checked out some of your other designs..RC, guns, printing..good stuff! I ended up scaling the A1 handle 2% and it's so close to perfect fit. comments.text: Are you running an all metal hot end? When I upgraded my RostockMax to an E3D v6 I had MAJOR issues with PLA until I starting using an oiler. Same when I upgraded my MakerSelect to all metal MicroSwiss. Now I can print PLA super smooth and no jams.
comments.author: gwidgery

comments.text: It's just a stock MakerBot 2X, We reworked the stepstruder to a dual gear drive system, but haven't messed around much with anything below that.  It works pretty good with ABS, reliable enough that I can hit print and not have to watch it constantly to get a good print.  I was planning on finish sanding my parts and painting them, but I never really did and just ran with it as is.  I don't mind trimming support, we tried a while back to use the water soluble PLA from MakerBot, but we couldn't get it to work right.  I put my own support in the rail groove because at the time we couldn't change the parameters for support in MakerWare and it kept printing it without support because the span was below the threshold for support needed, so I just modeled my own in SolidWorks and ran with it.  Stoked to see the pics.  I use mine everyday and it usually attracts a lot of attention.
comments.author: superpotatofudge

comments.text: Finally got a good carry handle from the REV 2 Punisher edition! I posted pics of it over under the listing for it.

comments.text: We thought about trying the oil thing back when we were having issues, but didn't want to make a huge mess of everything.  The mods we made to the stepper worked pretty well, it just took any adjustment out of the stepstruder and the PLA runs a little smaller diameter filament than the ABS does.  I'll keep it in mind though if we ever try to run PLA again.

title: Robo3D R1 Hexagon parts fan shroud

description.text: Improves airflow across the Robo's extruder nozzle to improve bridging and overhang performance. Designed to fit directly on to the current generation R1 with hexagon extruder. Should be printed with ABS or other materials with a high GT temperature My original design narrowed right down to blow air only across the nozzle however given the extremely limited space this would choke the fan resulting in pitiful airflow. This more open design blows air across the whole hot end and is much more effective. Bonus points if you print it with thermochromic material :)
30/01/2015 - Added hot end shield to reduce airflow across the hot end without reducing airflow at the nozzle. Tested with [email protected]°C
29/03/2015 - Reduced the size of the base from 40mm to 38mm

description.text:
Keyblade. This is a full size replica of the keyblade from the game Kingdom Hearts. Printable on a 140 x 140 bed. (up printer etc) My son and I put this together for a SFX trial to make some example game cut scenes. You can see the results of my sons work look here;
http://youtu.be/1B0VkVHn4_s

To make the keyblade:
Get a 500mm length of 42mm drainpipe from your local DIY store. If your in the USA and have access to 1-3/4" OD x 1-5/8" ID pipe then print the USA blade parts
keyblade_blade_base_usa.stl
keyblade_blade_a_usa.stl
keyblade_blade_b_usa.stl
keyblade_blade_c_usa.stl
keyblade_blade_d_usa.stl
keyblade_blade_e_usa.stl otherwise print the parts
keyblade_blade_base.stl
keyblade_blade_a.stl
keyblade_blade_b.stl
keyblade_blade_c.stl
keyblade_blade_d.stl
keyblade_blade_e.stl Print one of all the parts except the following
keyblade_handle_a - 2 off
keyblade_handle_e - 2 off.
chain_link2 - 3 off
chain_link - 12 off Assembly:
Glue the hilt and the handle together using small lengths of 1.75mm filament as guides. The peg is used to locate and fix the keyblade_blade_base. If you have a 3mm filament printer then you could drill out the indexing holes to fit, they will still work. Glue the keyblade_blade_d tube into the base of the assembled keyblade_blade and into the 500mm tube. Glue the hilt to the other side of the tube. Using a 2mm drill and lengths of filament (or 3mm as required) to pin the tube to the hilt. once the glue is dry trim off any excess filament. The chain_link2 is used with the clasp_body to attach to the hilt. glue the remaining chain_link_2 parts together through the base of the clasp_body to make a circular link.
Using the chain_link parts assemble the remainder of the chain remembering to link them before gluing. Finally link the mickey medallion when you glue the final link. Using car body filler fill any gaps and sand down before painting. We used some fabric looking tape on the handle to give it a leather look. This will not stand up to throwing around or hitting things! This is a decorative prop and you are entirely responsible for your own actions.

This is a modification of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:348861, correcting the ball placement for vertical printing. The original always placed the balls in the center of the open space, and spaced the balls apart; This causes problems when printing the model, since the balls start in mid air (don't know about your printer; mine really doesn't like this). This makes for a much happier printer, and a better print of the model.

author: taiwanuser

description.text: This is a sphere made of gears. The hub of the gears is off-center so that the surface breaks up when the gears turn. This is based on emmett's cube gears ( http://thingiverse.com/thing:6073 ), but with a lot of improvements to the script. Rendering still takes a long time at first (as much as 10 minutes for this version), but I've added caching so that you don't have to wait that long every time. The render statements I used to do this also stop the OpenCSG renderings from looking like something homicidal impressionist clown with dyslexia painted during an earthquake. I also made the animation work, though even with the caching it won't exceed a few fps. The most important thing, though, is that I added a module to the parameters section to define the shape to cut into gears. You can now make gears out of any STL just by dropping the "import_stl" into this module.

The gears are pretty similar, but it will only become a smooth sphere if it is assembled just right, so you should number them as you finish printing them. While looking at the center with any four faces visible, mark one of the large faces with a 1, then 2-3 moving clockwise from there. Face 5 is adjacent to 1 and 4, and if you turn the center piece so that side 5 and the remaining three sides are visible, you can number them in a counter-clockwise direction. You can also place them by identifying them in the OpenCSG rendering; gears 1 and 2 are grey, gears 3 and 4 are red, gears 5 and 6 are green, and gears 7 and 8 are blue (even-numbered gears are small, odd-numbered gears are large).
You can assemble them by threading M3 screws into the plastic of the center block. Use 16-18mm screws for the large gears and 18-20mm screws for the small gears.

A model of the chakra blades owned by Asuma and Shikamaru in Naruto. Designed after references from the manga. Made by Alex at Mirrored Line Props

Stl is formatted for full size printing with holes designed to be held.  I printed at .2mm with 10% infill.  Rafts and supports were used for good measure.  
I have included the 123dx file so that you can alter it for design or hand size.  For a look that is more accurate to the design, make the finger holes smaller and further apart.  To make a copy, extrude the outline up, extrude the finger holes up to subtract, and chamfer the blade edges together.  Scale as you like from there.

from Kirby.

I love playing the board game Settlers of Catan and I also love the video games from Blizzard so when I got a 3D printer the first big project I wanted to tackle was to recreate the board and pieces in 3D with the pieces being from Blizzard Games. The board is mainly modeled after the Warcraft III scenery. If you want to make this you will still need to buy the game to get the necessary cards and such. I made enough tiles for the 6 player version. If you only want the 4 player version you don’t need to make all of these. I’ll be posting the other board tiles in different posts. For the thief in order to tie in another Blizzard game I took this Diablo model and added a base.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18364 For the number tiles I used these:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40886
(you may want to print at 95%. Mine were a tight fit) To learn more go to:
https://recklessrobbie.wordpress.com
